threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Fat loss Assist Thread
Because weight loss start at /ck/ and not /fit/

>Who is /fat/ for?
For ducks and nuns who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.
Be a ketolard

Then my friend took me to some sekrit club bar that doesn't pay taxes and the novelty inhouse cocktails there were fucking amazing and delicious, didn't taste like anything concrete and I couldn't even discern the individual ingredients too much.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18586364

Yeah, once something starts going into a state change all the energy absorbed goes towards that state change. Water boils at 212 F, if you try to apply more heat then more water will start to convert to steam, but the water that’s still in liquid form will not exceed 212 F.

This is part of the reason that moisture is the enemy of good cooking: to evaporate moisture off the surface of food requires energy which goes towards that state change rather than increasing the temperature of the surface of the food. Slow cook barbecue “stalls” because large amounts of water begin to evaporate off the meat, sapping heat and preventing the temperature from increasing.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: How do I build a kitchen from scratch?
threads.com:
I've just moved out of my parents house very recently. I'm currently living in an apartment downtown surviving on microwave meals. I have nothing at all in my kitchen right now. Just the appliances that came with the place.

I'm not a /ck/ expert I only shitpost here occasionally so please inform me. What should I buy to start building up my kitchen? Should I get a high quality (if expensive) set of pots and pans to use long-term or just start off with cheap stuff from Target, what kind of pots/pans do I need to start, what spices do I need, are there any small appliances like rice cookers that are mandatory? I've never bought any of this stuff for myself before. This is a whole new world I'm stepping into.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18585665
>just get some wooden or silicone utensils
i suggest silicone because wood will harbor bacteria if cleaned improperly.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18585538
>Get a dutch oven
>A kettle and a toaster too
bad opinion

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Avoid buying sets of things like pots/pans. Measuring cups are an exception just because of how generic they are.

Pre-stocked spice spinners and knife blocks are a waste of money and space. Look at the price of a knife block set, and use that as a budget for one santoku knife. The fancier it looks, the more likely it's shit trying to sell to people who don't know anything about knives.

Grab a single grit 1000 whetstone and flattening stone eventually. Never purchase a whetstone that has two grits to save money. You want as flat a surface as possible when sharpening your knife, and you'll never get that with two sides getting uneven wear. One side is up. You sharpen your knife on the upside.

Get some salt and whole pepper corns to start with, and maybe cayenne or chili powder. If you have an Indian grocery store in town, consider getting whole spices from there, but you'll need something to store them in after opening. You don't want an entire cupboard of nothing but old spices you bought for one recipe and never looked at again which is what those spice spinners will turn into eventually.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
pro cook here
presuming you have a stove, oven, fridge and freezer, i'd recommend to start:
a chefs knife, probably 8". you can get something decent in the $30-50 range at a restuarant supply store. a paring knife is useful but i wouldnt spend much on one. bread knife is also handy for things other than bread but i hardly use mine
chopping board, not glass
a large skillet - non stick is fine for a noob, just don't put it in the oven and replace it when it gets scratched. if you get more into cooking you will know what to upgrade to. if you are a teflon-schizo then get a carbon steel pan
a small pot and a big pot
some kind of casserole dish, whether it's metal, pyrex, dutch oven, whatever. dutch oven doubles as a big pot but will probably be more expensive than buying the two separately, also it can't be in the oven and on the stove at the same time
a baking sheet
a spatula, a whisk, a ladle, a wooden spoon, tongs, a slotted spoon. if you go for non-stick don't buy metal utensils
a seive/colander/strainer
a box grater
a measuring jug, cups, spoons. a big enough measuring jug doubles as a mixing bowl
stuff to store your prepped/cooked food in
a honing rod, knife autists who are trying to split the atom will say you need whetstones as well but the average home cook might only need to use them once or twice a year so you could skip the expense for now

as for spices, it depends on what you like to eat. follow recipes and buy what you need as you need it. once you have a few staple dishes down you'll be restocking the same ones regularly

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18585527
The only mandatory things are a chef's knife, a pan, a wide shallow pot, a deep pot, and a cutting board. Rice cookers are for people who don't know how to cook rice, but get a cheap used one if you really want one. Ignore all the people telling you to get a bunch of crap, you're new to this and you'll be able to buy better stuff when you establish yourself more in a few years anyway. Get old stuff from people you know too. Ignore any people telling you to get a machine or a stone or rod to sharpen your knife, get a coffee mug and run it along the rim on the bottom at a 20 degree angle on both sides for a while. Keep it basic at first, grab more stuff that you find that you need later

last_replies.name: Anonymous

In the UK muffins are traditionally a type of bread (a roll). A crumpet is more like a pancake/blini with a looser consistency that is held in place by pouring it into a chef ring (looks like a cookie cutter) on a flat pan on the stove. The crumpet has deep holes through which added butter melts into. You take a bite and get a mouthful of rich buttery deliciousness.

Bratwurst is the easiest. Just lean meat like pork shoulder and something fatty like belly or fatback. Fat content should be around 30%. Seasoning always contains salt, black and/or white pepper and especially mace. Common aditions are cardamom, dried ginger, allspice and lemon zests. Onions are almost mandatory when you want to make fine bratwurst which is more complicated though as you need a bowl cutter, ice and phosphate. A pot of water with a constant temperature of 76-78°c to scald them would also be good to have.

>>18586478
Oops I’m retarded I tried to copypaste the whole explanation and only got the last paragraph.

I eyeballed it but everything is pretty basic and logical. Marinaded the chicken in buttermilk but you can use whatever you want. I just wanted to make sure it would be tender. Then bread in flour seasoned with salt, pepper, paprika, cayenne, and garlic powder. Fried at 300 degrees for about 6 minutes. Set aside on a wire rack in a low oven cuz frying everything takes a while.

Fries are standard. Chop, soak, dry, fry. I double fry at 350 for a few minutes then at 400 (or higher) for 90 seconds to crisp them up. Season with salt, chives if you have em on-hand.

The sauce is just thousand island so do whatever you want. I used mayo, ketchup, worsnejchire sauce, salt, pepper, garlic, and the juice of half a lemon I had on hand. The mayo is about 75% the volume of the whole thing, and I made around 2 cups of it.

It’s an easy recipe but the frying takes a long time. We made enough for leftovers that hopefully won’t suck so it’ll offset the work a bit.

threads.sub: You'll cowards don't even grow squash
threads.com:
I notice that /ck/ has an undercurrent of food-related prepping and gardening. But many of you don't really know WHAT to grow, beyond the obvious stuff like potatoes or corn. The answer is squash. Squashes can be cleaned and stored for up to a year after harvest. They are full of nutrients. They are versatile in terms of cooking and recipes. They can be canned or stored for longer periods of time. And they aren't very difficult to grow in temperate climates.

There are thousands of varieties of squash, but beginners should start with the Cucurbita maxima, AKA the 'blue hubbard.' Blue hubbards have dense, rich flesh which is prized for its texture and taste. They grow to respectable sizes, but aren't absurdly huge like pumpkins (a late-season healthy Hubbard should be anywhere from 10 to 20lbs / 4.5-9kg, or a bit bigger if they start earlier in the season). They have a rugged outer skin which helps ward off predators and damage. And they have a good aesthetic in general. Peeled and cubed hubbard fits great in stews and soups.

If you have limited experience with squashes or gardening, this is a good way to start. You can easily grow a dozen or more mature hubbards from a small number of plants and their vines, even with relatively limited space. That's a couple hundred pounds of fresh, high-quality, nutrient-rich food. And beyond that, there are many other squashes to grow.

You WILL grow some squashes the next time your local planting season comes around - right, /ck/?
